• ID: {{ia-5.1_smt}}, Name: statement - For password-based authentication:
    • item: {{ia-5.1_smt.a}} - Maintain a list of commonly-used, expected, or compromised passwords and update the list {{ ia-5.1_prm_1 }} and when organizational passwords are suspected to have been compromised directly or indirectly;
    • item: {{ia-5.1_smt.b}} - Verify, when users create or update passwords, that the passwords are not found on the list of commonly-used, expected, or compromised passwords in IA-5(1)(a);
    • item: {{ia-5.1_smt.c}} - Transmit passwords only over cryptographically-protected channels;
    • item: {{ia-5.1_smt.d}} - Store passwords using an approved salted key derivation function, preferably using a keyed hash;
    • item: {{ia-5.1_smt.e}} - Require immediate selection of a new password upon account recovery;

    • item: {{ia-5.1_smt.g}} - Employ automated tools to assist the user in selecting strong password authenticators; and

• item: {{pl-2_smt.a}} - Develop security and privacy plans for the system that:
      • item: {{pl-2_smt.a.1}} - Are consistent with the organization’s enterprise architecture;
      • item: {{pl-2_smt.a.2}} - Explicitly define the constituent system components;
      • item: {{pl-2_smt.a.3}} - Describe the operational context of the system in terms of mission and business processes;
      • item: {{pl-2_smt.a.4}} - Identify the individuals that fulfill system roles and responsibilities;
      • item: {{pl-2_smt.a.5}} - Identify the information types processed, stored, and transmitted by the system;
      • item: {{pl-2_smt.a.6}} - Provide the security categorization of the system, including supporting rationale;
      • item: {{pl-2_smt.a.7}} - Describe any specific threats to the system that are of concern to the organization;
      • item: {{pl-2_smt.a.8}} - Provide the results of a privacy risk assessment for systems processing personally identifiable information;
      • item: {{pl-2_smt.a.9}} - Describe the operational environment for the system and any dependencies on or connections to other systems or system components;
      • item: {{pl-2_smt.a.10}} - Provide an overview of the security and privacy requirements for the system;
      • item: {{pl-2_smt.a.11}} - Identify any relevant control baselines or overlays, if applicable;
      • item: {{pl-2_smt.a.12}} - Describe the controls in place or planned for meeting the security and privacy requirements, including a rationale for any tailoring decisions;
      • item: {{pl-2_smt.a.13}} - Include risk determinations for security and privacy architecture and design decisions;
      • item: {{pl-2_smt.a.14}} - Include security- and privacy-related activities affecting the system that require planning and coordination with {{ pl-2_prm_1 }}; and
      • item: {{pl-2_smt.a.15}} - Are reviewed and approved by the authorizing official or designated representative prior to plan implementation.
    • item: {{pl-2_smt.b}} - Distribute copies of the plans and communicate subsequent changes to the plans to {{ pl-2_prm_2 }};
    • item: {{pl-2_smt.c}} - Review the plans {{ pl-2_prm_3 }};
    • item: {{pl-2_smt.d}} - Update the plans to address changes to the system and environment of operation or problems identified during plan implementation or control assessments; and
    • item: {{pl-2_smt.e}} - Protect the plans from unauthorized disclosure and modification.

parts:
• ID: {{pt-7.1_smt}}, Name: statement - When a system processes Social Security numbers:
    • item: {{pt-7.1_smt.a}} - Eliminate unnecessary collection, maintenance, and use of Social Security numbers, and explore alternatives to their use as a personal identifier;
    • item: {{pt-7.1_smt.b}} - Do not deny any individual any right, benefit, or privilege provided by law because of such individual’s refusal to disclose his or her Social Security number; and
    • item: {{pt-7.1_smt.c}} - Inform any individual who is asked to disclose his or her Social Security number whether that disclosure is mandatory or voluntary, by what statutory or other authority such number is solicited, and what uses will be made of it.

title: Use of Information Assurance Products
parts:
• item: {{sa-4.6_smt.a}} - Employ only government off-the-shelf or commercial off-the-shelf information assurance and information assurance-enabled information technology products that compose an NSA-approved solution to protect classified information when the networks used to transmit the information are at a lower classification level than the information being transmitted; and
    • item: {{sa-4.6_smt.b}} - Ensure that these products have been evaluated and/or validated by NSA or in accordance with NSA-approved procedures.

title: Niap-approved Protection Profiles
parts:
• item: {{sa-4.7_smt.a}} - Limit the use of commercially provided information assurance and information assurance-enabled information technology products to those products that have been successfully evaluated against a National Information Assurance partnership (NIAP)-approved Protection Profile for a specific technology type, if such a profile exists; and
    • item: {{sa-4.7_smt.b}} - Require, if no NIAP-approved Protection Profile exists for a specific technology type but a commercially provided information technology product relies on cryptographic functionality to enforce its security policy, that the cryptographic module is FIPS-validated or NSA-approved.

title: Continuous Monitoring Plan for Controls
parts: • ID: {{sa-4.8_smt}}, Name: statement - Require the developer of the system, system component, or system service to produce a plan for continuous monitoring of control effectiveness that is consistent with the continuous monitoring program of the organization.

title: Use of Approved Piv Products
parts: • ID: {{sa-4.10_smt}}, Name: statement - Employ only information technology products on the FIPS 201-approved products list for Personal Identity Verification (PIV) capability implemented within organizational systems.
